results.title: Safety oriented first aid. Unit 2
results.brief_description: One of a series of instructional first aid films. Explains the symptoms of shock, its causes and treatment. Shows fractures and dislocations; how they occur, and their treatment. Narrated by John Granik.

results.title: Safety in your hands
results.creator_credit: South Australian Film Corporation, John Fitzgerald and Jill Robb
results.brief_description:
This 1974 film examines the responsibility of each worker for their own safety in the workplace. The film focuses particularly on protection of hands and eyes in industrial settings, showing a variety of machines operated by people. It demonstrates how untidiness, inattention, overconfidence and failure to use safety precautions such as safety glasses when operating these machines can lead to accidents. Footage of industrial workplaces is interspersed with footage of everyday accidents similarly caused by mess, distraction and overconfidence.

Produced by the South Australian Film Corporation for the South Australian Department of Labour and Industry.

The colour is faded throughout the film.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Safety in the slaughterhouse
results.creator_credit: Camfilm Productions, Peter Johnson and John Bowen
results.brief_description:
This 1979 film is directed at meat inspectors working in abbatoirs. The film contains footage of workers in abbatoirs and close-ups of inspectors working on carcasses. It includes interviews with three inspectors about the accidents they suffered during their work and a discussion at the pub between a group of meat inspectors on the problems they encounter in their work and the safety precautions they should note.

Produced by Camfilm Productions for the Department of Primary Industry.

The colour is faded throughout the film.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Safety in the shop: power tools
results.brief_description: Stresses common sense practices in the use of woodworking and metal working machines, including the drill press, grinder, jointer, router and various types of power saws and lathes. Shows the need for proper clothing, machine guards, making adjustments before starting the machine, dealing with broken blades and the value of neatness.

results.title: Safety in the shop: hand tools
results.creator_credit: Moreland-Latchford Productions, Coronet Films, David Thompson and Mary Thompson
results.brief_description: Shows the value in both wood and metal shops of keeping hand tools in good condition, the need to keep saws and chisels sharp, and possible dangers from broken handles, worn tips and burrs. Emphasises the importance of protective clothing, and demonstrates safe use of the forge and welding equipment.

results.title: Safety in the shop: basic practices
results.brief_description: This film emphasises the worker’s responsibility for safety in both wood and metal shops in clothing, lifting and carrying. Important also are the values of tidiness and the taking of adequate precautions in fire prevention.
